course.subject: COMP
course.name: Data Visualization
course.description: This course will introduce visualization techniques for data from everyday life, social media, business, scientific computing, medical imaging, etc. The topics include human visual system and perception, visual design principles, open- source visualization tools and systems, visualization techniques for CT/MRI data, computational fluid dynamics, graphs and networks, time-series data, text and documents, Twitter data, and spatio-temporal data. The labs and the course project will give students hands-on experience to turn their favorite data into beautiful visualizations.
course.prerequisites: COMP 1021 OR COMP 1022P OR COMP 1022Q

reviews.author: Dreamer
reviews.title: A pretty good experience
reviews.comment_content: The course name is everything it contains. Data Visualization. From basic concept to practical method to real project, its content is quite comprehensive and consequently massive. That's also a challenge for students to remember so much knowledge if not interested. After all, its final tests everything from the course.
reviews.comment_teaching: The professor is really good. Despite his Chinglish, he gives high-quality lectures. In fact, his weird pronunciation is something attracts me to focus on class, too. He reads PPTs but reads them in a quite humorous way. Although I didn't attend the lectures very often (I am too lazy to get to the classroom...), I do enjoy his style of giving the lecture
reviews.comment_grading:
Project: 50%
Final 30%;
Written Assignment 10%
Attendance 10%

Project: carried by groupmates. Pretty good response from prof.
Final mean + sd
WA don't know. Didn't get a response
Attendance maybe 80%?

Final grade: A+
reviews.comment_workload:
If you don't put much effort into the group project, literally you won't have any workload.
That's what I have gone through. For the final, I just spent a whole day writing notes and reciting. For WA, I freestyle...
Oh btw, there are three pre3 through the semester. That may require some workload.
